hints.content:
**Area** is the space a flat shape fills.

To measure area, we can count the number of **same-sized** square units needed to cover a shape. The squares should have **no gaps or overlaps**.

![A square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e84bf2b2e3d1e5e75c9583276f68463f72f10826) is $1$ **square unit** because it measures $1$ unit on each side.

This shape has $4$ square units covering it. There are no gaps or overlaps.

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has one square, and the third row has two squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e6030a1279acb9ae6e74e4ba6796f9f72f5bde1b)

So, this shape has an area of $4$ square units.

This shape has $4$ square units covering it. There are no gaps or overlaps.

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has two squares, and the third row has one square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e9b17ef7efb1aaeff6dc497076d507db7220f0f0)

So, this shape has an area of $4$ square units.

This shape has $6$ square units covering it, not $4$:
  
![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has two squares, the second row has two squares, and the third row has two squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a630be0d498de18f3fd6a01af2a8c4d383992cfb)

This shape has $16$ square units covering it, not $4$:
  
![A figure made up of four rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has four squares, the second row has four squares, the third row has four  squares, and the fourth row has four squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9303324551bae0fc284468227c9124529e47c996)

These shapes have an area of $4$ square units:

![Two figures are shown.  The first figure is made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has two squares, and the third row has one square. The second figure is made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has one square, and the third row has two squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e9b17ef7efb1aaeff6dc497076d507db7220f0f0)  ![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e6030a1279acb9ae6e74e4ba6796f9f72f5bde1b)

question.content:
**Which shapes have an area of $4$ square units?**

![A square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e84bf2b2e3d1e5e75c9583276f68463f72f10826) is $1$ square unit.

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has one square, and the third row has two squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e6030a1279acb9ae6e74e4ba6796f9f72f5bde1b)

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has one square, the second row has two squares, and the third row has one square.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/e9b17ef7efb1aaeff6dc497076d507db7220f0f0)

![A figure made up of three rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has two squares, the second row has two squares, and the third row has two squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a630be0d498de18f3fd6a01af2a8c4d383992cfb)

![A figure made up of four rows of equal-sized squares connected together. The first row has four squares, the second row has four squares, the third row has four  squares, and the fourth row has four squares.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9303324551bae0fc284468227c9124529e47c996)
